intro: Ifloga spicata var. labillardierei, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a perennial herb native to New Zealand. It belongs to the Asparagaceae family and is characterized by its tall, erect stems and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers in dense spikes, which appear in late spring to early summer. It is well adapted to coastal and wetland environments, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. This variety is notable for its historical use by Māori for weaving and its ecological importance in native ecosystems.
